<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 379, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 211, 425, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 211, 905, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 260, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 760, 559]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 730, 635]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 905, 842]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use

Total
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 867, 727, 884]]<|/det|> This document has 16 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the behaviour of a spring and use it to determine the density of modelling clay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 490, 136]]<|/det|>
A stand and spring have been set up for you.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 680, 168]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 178, 616, 300]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 314, 532, 333]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 346, 146, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 345, 588, 365]]<|/det|>
Measure the length \(l_0\) of the spring without any load.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 390, 920, 410]]<|/det|>
<form>\(l_0 = ............................................................ \text{cm}\) [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 439, 146, 458]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 438, 761, 458]]<|/det|>
Suspend a load of weight \(W = 2.0 \text{N}\) from the spring, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 467, 630, 696]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 712, 534, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 744, 183, 762]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 744, 561, 762]]<|/det|>
Measure the stretched length \(l\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 789, 920, 808]]<|/det|>
<form>\(l =\) .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 820, 148, 839]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 820, 764, 839]]<|/det|>
Calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring for a load of weight \(W = 2.0 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 835, 720, 855]]<|/det|>
Use your values from (a) and (b)(i) and the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 881, 920, 900]]<|/det|>
<form>e = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 881, 920, 900]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 433, 89]]<|/det|>
Remove the load from the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 730, 120]]<|/det|>
Suspend the load U, which is made of modelling clay, from the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 532, 152]]<|/det|>
Measure the stretched length \(l_{\mathrm{U}}\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 177, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<form>l<sub>U</sub> = .................................................... cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 586, 229]]<|/det|>
Calculate the extension \(e_{\mathrm{U}}\) of the spring with load U.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 256, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<form>e<sub>U</sub> = .................................................... cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 761, 307]]<|/det|>
The extension of a spring is directly proportional to the weight of the load.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 922, 354]]<|/det|>
Use your values of \(W\) and \(e\) from **(b)(ii)** and your value of \(e_{\mathrm{U}}\) to determine the weight \(W_{\mathrm{U}}\) of load U.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 322, 368]]<|/det|>
Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[536, 482, 920, 501]]<|/det|>
<form>W<sub>U</sub> = ...........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 500, 920, 517]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Fully immerse load U in the beaker of water, as shown in Fig. 1.3. The load U must **not** touch either the sides or the bottom of the beaker.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 111, 719, 395]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 408, 534, 427]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 440, 537, 460]]<|/det|>
Measure the stretched length \(l_{\mathrm{W}}\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 484, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
<form>\(l_{\mathrm{W}} =\) .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 516, 690, 536]]<|/det|>
Calculate the extension \(e_{\mathrm{W}}\) of the spring with load U in the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[539, 562, 920, 583]]<|/det|>
<form>\(e_{\mathrm{W}} =\) .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 594, 524, 613]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the modelling clay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 609, 690, 628]]<|/det|>
Use your value of \(e_{\mathrm{U}}\) from **(c)**, your value of \(e_{\mathrm{W}}\) and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 632, 667, 667]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{\mathsf{e}_{\mathsf{U}}}{(\mathsf{e}_{\mathsf{U}} - \mathsf{e}_{\mathsf{W}})}\times k,\mathrm{~where~}k = 1.0\mathsf{g / cm}^{3}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 733, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho =\) .................................................... $\text{g/cm}^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 749, 920, 768]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 781, 144, 799]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 780, 850, 799]]<|/det|>
Suggest a possible source of inaccuracy in the determination of \(\rho\) in this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 871, 920, 890]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 143, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Describe one precaution that you took when measuring the length of the spring, to ensure an accurate reading. You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 268, 920, 286]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 146, 318]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 300, 920, 333]]<|/det|>
A student plots a graph of load against extension for the spring, to show that the two quantities are directly proportional.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 346, 816, 364]]<|/det|>
State how his graph line shows that load and extension are directly proportional.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 454, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 484, 920, 502]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the electromotive force (e.m.f.) and resistance of a cell by using a resistance wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 118, 411, 135]]<|/det|> The circuit has been set up for you. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 576, 166]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 175, 829, 522]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 537, 532, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 565, 144, 583]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 565, 299, 583]]<|/det|> Close the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 596, 920, 628]]<|/det|> Attach the crocodile clip to the resistance wire. Adjust its position until the value \(V\) of the potential difference (p.d.) across the cell and the resistor is 5.0V. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 642, 915, 658]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the value of the current \(I\) for the cell and resistor in series. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 672, 920, 704]]<|/det|> Repeat this procedure for values of \(V = 4.5 \text{V}, 4.0 \text{V}, 3.5 \text{V}\) and \(3.0 \text{V}\). Detach the crocodile clip from the resistance wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 720, 298, 736]]<|/det|> Open the switch. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 750, 541, 767]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 774, 621, 925]]<|/det|>
V/VI/A
5.0
4.5
4.0
3.5
3.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 926, 920, 944]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 834, 91]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(I / \mathrm{A}\) (y-axis) against \(V / \mathrm{V}\) (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 103, 776, 562]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 598, 144, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 598, 680, 617]]<|/det|>
The e.m.f. \(E\) of the cell is equal to the value of \(V\) when \(I = 0.0 \text{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 628, 494, 647]]<|/det|>
Determine the value of \(E\) from the graph.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 694, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
<form>E = ....................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 151, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<form>G = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 185, 181, 203]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 180, 920, 225]]<|/det|>
The value of \(\frac{1}{G}\) is numerically equal to the resistance \((r + R)\) where \(r\) is the resistance of the cell and \(R = 5.0 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 237, 495, 255]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance \(r\) of the cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 303, 920, 321]]<|/det|>
<form>r = .................................................... \(\Omega\) [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 146, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 333, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
Suggest how the experiment and graph could be improved to obtain a more accurate value for e.m.f. \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 466, 920, 485]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 798, 88]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light by a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 85, 828, 103]]<|/det|>
You will determine a quantity known as the refractive index of the material of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 165, 129, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>hole</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 170, 910, 650]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 667, 532, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 698, 144, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 698, 920, 732]]<|/det|>
Place the block approximately in the centre of the ray-trace sheet. Carefully draw round the block and label the corners ABCD as indicated by Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 728, 554, 745]]<|/det|>
Remove the block from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 744, 920, 777]]<|/det|>
Draw a normal to line AB at a point N, 2 cm from \(\mathbf{A}\). Extend the normal downwards until it crosses the line CD. Label the point at which it crosses CD with the letter F.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 775, 821, 792]]<|/det|>
Draw a line NE, as indicated by Fig. 3.1, 8 cm long and at an angle \(\theta_{1} = 20^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 791, 920, 809]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 72, 655, 91]]<|/det|>
Replace the block in exactly the same position as in **(a)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 175, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 87, 915, 120]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line **NE**, a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 103, 175, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 465, 123]]<|/det|>
Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 120, 173, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 119, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
View the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the block from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), a suitable distance apart, so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), all appear exactly one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 165, 175, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 165, 465, 184]]<|/det|>
Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 181, 175, 200]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 180, 628, 200]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and pins from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 196, 175, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 196, 715, 215]]<|/det|>
Draw a line joining \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Extend this line until it meets **NF**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 212, 175, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 210, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which this line meets **NF** with the letter **G**. Label the point at which this line crosses **CD** with the letter **H**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 242, 175, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 242, 482, 260]]<|/det|>
Draw a line joining points **N** and **H**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 259, 920, 276]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 288, 144, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 425, 306]]<|/det|>
Measure the length \(a\) of line **NH**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 333, 920, 351]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 425, 384]]<|/det|>
Measure the length \(b\) of line **GH**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 411, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
<form>b = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 735, 467]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value \(n_1\) for the refractive index, using the equation \(n_1 = \frac{a}{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 512, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<form>n_1 = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 559, 146, 577]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 559, 821, 578]]<|/det|>
Draw a new line **NE**, as indicated by Fig. 3.1, \(8\mathrm{cm}\) long and at an angle \(\theta_2 = 40^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 590, 353, 609]]<|/det|>
Repeat the steps in **(b)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 622, 181, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 622, 532, 640]]<|/det|>
Measure the length \(c\) of the new line **NH**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 668, 920, 686]]<|/det|>
<form>c = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 700, 534, 718]]<|/det|>
Measure the length \(d\) of the new line **GH**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 745, 920, 763]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 778, 848, 802]]<|/det|>
Calculate a second value \(n_2\) for the refractive index, using the equation \(n_2 = \frac{c}{d}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 878, 920, 897]]<|/det|>
<form>n_2 = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 903, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the factors affecting the deflection of a wooden strip clamped at one end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how **one** factor affects the distance \(D\) that the free end of the wooden strip moves downwards when loads are placed on it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 522, 166]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 398, 198]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 211, 710, 229]]<|/det|>
a variety of wooden strips that can be clamped as shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 227, 410, 244]]<|/det|>
a set of masses with a hanger.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 258, 324, 275]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 138, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 288, 457, 306]]<|/det|>
list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 138, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 320, 507, 338]]<|/det|>
state the key variables to be kept constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 133, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 351, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how to carry out the experiment, including how \(D\) is to be measured and any precautions that must be taken to ensure reliable results

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 133, 415]]<|/det|>
